title: ion-loading
body: An overlay that can be used to indicate activity while blocking user interaction. The loading indicator appears on top of the app's content, and can be dismissed by the app to resume user interaction with the app. It includes an optional backdrop, which can be disabled by setting
The loading indicator can be dismissed automatically after a specific amount of time by passing the number of milliseconds to display it in the
of the loading options. To dismiss the loading indicator after creation, call the
method on the loading instance. The
function can be called to perform an action after the loading indicator is dismissed.
Loading uses scoped encapsulation, which means it will automatically scope its CSS by appending each of the styles with an additional class at runtime. Overriding scoped selectors in CSS requires a
We recommend passing a custom class to
method and using that to add custom styles to the host and inner elements. This property can also accept multiple classes separated by spaces. View the
section for an example of how to pass a class using
/* DOES NOT WORK - not specific enough */
/* Works - pass "my-custom-class" in cssClass to increase specificity */
can be used to style the Loading without needing to target individual elements:
If you are building an Ionic Angular app, the styles need to be added to a global stylesheet file. Read
in the Angular section below for more information.

angular: In Angular, the CSS of a specific page is scoped only to elements of that page. Even though the Loading can be presented from within a page, the
element is appended outside of the current page. This means that any custom styles need to go in a global stylesheet file. In an Ionic Angular starter this can be the
file or you can register a new global style file by

props.name: backdropDismiss
props.docs: If true, the loading indicator will be dismissed when the backdrop is clicked.

props.name: cssClass
props.docs: Additional classes to apply for custom CSS. If multiple classes are provided they should be separated by spaces.

props.name: duration
props.docs: Number of milliseconds to wait before dismissing the loading indicator.

props.name: enterAnimation
props.docs: Animation to use when the loading indicator is presented.

props.name: keyboardClose
props.docs: If true, the keyboard will be automatically dismissed when the overlay is presented.

props.name: leaveAnimation
props.docs: Animation to use when the loading indicator is dismissed.

props.name: message
props.docs: Optional text content to display in the loading indicator.

props.name: mode
props.docs: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

props.name: showBackdrop
props.docs: If true, a backdrop will be displayed behind the loading indicator.

props.name: spinner
props.docs: The name of the spinner to display.

props.name: translucent
props.docs: If true, the loading indicator will be translucent. Only applies when the mode is "ios" and the device supports backdrop-filter.

methods.name: dismiss
methods.signature: dismiss(data?: any, role?: string | undefined) => Promise<boolean>
methods.docs: Dismiss the loading overlay after it has been presented.

docsTags.name: param
docsTags.text: data Any data to emit in the dismiss events.

docsTags.name: param
docsTags.text:
role The role of the element that is dismissing the loading.
This can be useful in a button handler for determining which button was
clicked to dismiss the loading.
Some examples include: ``"cancel"`, `"destructive"`, "selected"`, and `"backdrop"`.

methods.name: onDidDismiss
methods.docs: Returns a promise that resolves when the loading did dismiss.

methods.name: onWillDismiss
methods.docs: Returns a promise that resolves when the loading will dismiss.

methods.name: present
methods.docs: Present the loading overlay after it has been created.

docs: An overlay that can be used to indicate activity while blocking user interaction. The loading indicator appears on top of the app's content, and can be dismissed by the app to resume user interaction with the app. It includes an optional backdrop, which can be disabled by setting `showBackdrop: false` upon creation.

docsTags.text: {"ios" | "md"} mode - The mode determines which platform styles to use.
docsTags.name: virtualProp

events.docs: Emitted after the loading has dismissed.
Emitted after the loading has presented.
Emitted before the loading has dismissed.
Emitted before the loading has presented.

styles.name: --max-height
styles.docs: Maximum height of the loading dialog

styles.name: --max-width
styles.docs: Maximum width of the loading dialog

styles.name: --min-height
styles.docs: Minimum height of the loading dialog

styles.name: --min-width
styles.docs: Minimum width of the loading dialog
